issue.title: Line number always takes precendence when running with filters.
When an example group location is specified from CLI, apply filtering on nested examples and groups
issue.body:
This is a follow up to rspec/rspec-core#779 (as well as rspec/rspec-core#1474, the partial fix that was put in place to address rspec/rspec-core#779).

Currently, examples that match a location filter (e.g. via `rspec path/to/spec.rb:47`) all run, even if they are tagged in a way that matches an exclusion filter.  In rspec/rspec-core#1474 it was discussed that the ideal behavior is that when the line number of an individual example matches, it would always run regardless of exclusions but when the line number matches an example group, exclusion filters on nested examples and example groups should still apply.

This is also related to rspec/rspec-core#1484, but is a bit different -- `:if` and `:unless` filters should be treated a bit different IMO.

issue.title: Tags specified on the command line are ignored when filtering examples by line-number
issue.body:
We have a `:slow` tag applied to some integration specs. In our RSpec configuration, we exclude `:slow` specs by default. However, if we try to run a particular example from the command line with `rspec -t slow spec/integration/some_spec.rb:42`, nothing runs.  

```
Run options:
  include {:locations=>{"./spec/integration/some_spec.rb"=>[42]}}
  exclude {:slow=>true}

Finished in 0.00008 seconds
0 examples, 0 failures
```

It appears that the presence of a line-number filter on the command line clobbers any requested tags.

body: I can take care of this one.

issue.title: Ensure standalone inclusions don't clear exclusions
